On November 3, Mikuláš Ferjenčík started a new discussion thread on the Pirate Forum called " Establishment of a Party Ombudsman / Mediation Team ". The purpose of this thread is to determine whether to establish an institution within the Pirate Party that would aim to resolve internal party conflicts and create peace and consensus. At the same time, it should be an advisory institution where members could go if they felt that someone else in the party was treating them inappropriately. This thread also discusses the question of how to fill this position and whether it should be an internal or external institution. This thread also discussed the question of whether it must be experts or whether listening to empathetic party members would be sufficient.

Ivan Bartoš divided his contribution to the forum into three parts. The first part concerns what the Pirates can resolve themselves, in the second part he focused on their own processes and their compliance, and in the third part he dealt with the mediation team, the ombudsman. In the third part of his contribution, he expressed himself in such a way that he would imagine an external institution and that it should be experts. He further stated: "For my part, I would like the Pirates to have resolved everything that is possible, including, for example, the selection of a partner to resolve these issues, by Christmas this year."

A poll question was attached to this thread : "Do you consider the establishment of an ombudsman or mediation team a good idea?" The possible answers to this poll are Yes, No, and I don't know. 85 out of 100 voters voted in favor of establishing this institution, 6 voters were against, and 9 voters chose the I don't know option.

According to the Pirate Party's budget proposal for 2020, 300,000 crowns should be reserved for the creation of an ombudsman institution, a mediation team, or the hiring of a supervisor.

Ivan Bartoš and Olga Richterová jointly participated in the certificate presentation ceremony as part of the Roma Scholarship Program for Roma students in secondary schools and vocational schools , organized by Romeo. At the event, which took place on October 11 in the Brožík Hall of the Old Town Hall, they jointly gave a short speech in which they supported the project and spoke about the vision of accessible education for all.

The program is in its fourth year and 69 applicants received scholarships this year. The organization does not provide exact numbers of scholarship applicants, but it says that last year there were approximately 150 applications. However, in the same article, scholarship program manager Jitka Votavová states that limited funds allow for scholarships to be provided to only about a third of applicants, which would mean 180 applications, given the 60 scholarships awarded last year.

The caption on the recording of this year's ceremony, which was provided by the internet television ROMEA TV, states that the scholarship recipients were selected from "more than 130 applicants" ( video , caption under the video, which is shown from 6:15 to 6:34). In his opening remarks, the moderator Lukáš Kotlár said that "the interest in Roma scholarships is really great, up to 150 students apply for these scholarships within the framework of the Romea program every year" ( video , 2:56). The exact number for this year is therefore probably between 130 and 150 applicants. This corresponds to approximately twice the number of scholarships awarded.

The amount of scholarships for secondary school students is 14,000 CZK per school year, while the organization offers a higher scholarship grant to VOŠ students, namely 21,000 CZK per school year.

We therefore assess the statement as true. We do not assess the amount of the scholarship as a value judgment, just as we do not assess its relative amount for the awarded families.

Jindřich Šídlo actually used the phrase "toddlers with flamethrowers" in his show Happy Monday on September 30, 2019. Specifically, at 5 minutes and 32 seconds. The entire sentence reads: " These are the Pirates, or as we, traditional voters, toddlers with flamethrowers, who may soon rule us." He also describes, from his perspective, the coming of age of the party, the Pirate Party's plans for the next elections, and also the vote to dissolve the party, which is allegedly an exaggeration (time 1:31) and takes place every year.

The words "toddlers" and "toddlers" are different, but they share a common context.

However, the phrase "toddlers with flamethrowers" has been used several times in history. Specifically, in the program 168 hodin (time 8:00) broadcast on October 27, 2019, Václav Dolejší stated that he had read the term on Twitter . Before the broadcast, the term was mentioned on Twitter three times. On September 30, 2019, which could have been related to Jindřich Šídl's program. However, the absolute first traced mention of this term dates back to September 29, 2017, when Petr Honzejk mentioned it in Hospodářské noviny , saying that he found it on Josef Bouška's Facebook profile . We went through the posts, but we did not find the mention. However, the post may have been deleted.

Although the term "toddlers with flamethrowers" appeared before Jindřich Šídlo used it, he undoubtedly contributed significantly to its popularization, and we therefore assess the statement as true.

Bartoš is probably referring to Babiš's first minority government from December 2017 to July 2018, which did not gain the confidence of the Chamber of Deputies. Its draft amendment to the Civil Service Act was submitted to the Chamber on March 26, 2018, i.e. 2 months after submitting his resignation.

Given the terminology ("the first thing the government started to address"), it is more of a figure of speech than a factual statement that it should be the first law submitted. However, it is worth adding that this was not the first government bill since taking office . Between December 13, 2017 and March 26, 2018, the government submitted an amendment to the Act on the CNB, an amendment to the Act on the Transfer of Ownership, an amendment to the Act on the Organization and Implementation of Social Security, or an amendment to the Act on Pension Insurance. Even the Ministry of the Interior, as the representative of the proposer, did not submit an amendment to the Act on Civil Service as the first part of its agenda; it was preceded, for example, by an amendment to the Act on Elections to the Parliament of the Czech Republic.

In April 2018, the European Commission criticized the government's draft amendment to the Civil Service Act. As we read in a letter from European Commissioner for Employment Marianne Thyssen to the Deputy Minister of the Interior for the Civil Service, Josef Postránecký: " We therefore remain concerned about key elements of the proposal. For example, the shift to somewhat low requirements for the second rounds of selection procedures for management positions, the possibility of dismissing managers based on a 'sufficient' evaluation result, the possibility of dismissing civil servants based on two service evaluations within a 40-day period, and the deprivation of managers from the possibility of filing an objection against a service evaluation. " At the same time, the European Commissioner notes that the amendment was submitted to the Chamber of Deputies in March 2018 and asks to provide analytical materials that led to its form.

The government proposal (.pdf) for an amendment to Act No. 106/1999 Coll. , on free access to information, adds the following sentence to Section 2: "The Act shall not apply to the provision of information on ongoing criminal proceedings and persons participating in them, with the exception of information on court decisions on the merits." (.pdf, p. 28). The amendment to the Act would thus make it impossible to access information on ongoing criminal proceedings under Act No. 106/1999 Coll., including procedural decisions in the proceedings. Therefore, if a question were asked, it would be completely outside the competence of the Act and there would be no need to handle it.

In the current version of the Act on Free Access to Information , Section 11 already contains a ban on providing information on ongoing criminal proceedings (i.e. everything up to the decision in the case). The law therefore required that the request be processed in such a way that the information is not provided. However, this rule is broken by the case law ( judgment no. 1 As 44/2010 – 103, point 36) of the Supreme Administrative Court, which requires obliged entities to consider each individual case and, depending on the circumstances, to allow the provision of information on ongoing criminal proceedings where the failure to provide information cannot be justified by an “urgent social need”. Courts may therefore provide information on ongoing criminal proceedings despite the statutory ban, if the failure to provide information is not necessary.

According to the explanatory report (.pdf, p. 127) of the government amendment, this situation led to " a far-reaching burden on criminal justice authorities, who always had to justify in detail why information could not be provided (if they did not provide it), with difficulties arising from the question of how to argue without using the information itself".

If the government amendment were to enter into force, the obligation of authorities involved in criminal proceedings to provide reasons for (not) providing information during the proceedings, as established by case law, would cease. Only the obligation to provide information on the decision on the merits would be maintained. The public would thus not have access to information on ongoing criminal proceedings and procedural decisions, which are often crucial for the development of the proceedings. According to the NSS (point 38), providing information on ongoing criminal proceedings is often in the public interest, especially in cases involving criminal acts committed by officials or public officials. Such a case is, among others, the procedural resolution of the High Court in Prague in the David Rath case, by which the High Court rejected wiretapping as illegal.

The discussion of the amendment to the law in the third reading was included on the agenda of the 20th meeting and should take place on November 14, 2018.

Determine whether the statement is TRUE or FALSE based on the content and a number of short explanations with additional information. Only one of the following explanations is relevant: SECTION A:

By the term "pre-election", Pirates Chairman Bartoš probably means the 2017 post-election strategy , which the Pirates published before the 2017 elections to the Chamber of Deputies, the introduction of which states:

"We will negotiate with all other political parties. Our support for any government is conditional on the fact that incompetent people or people with a history of corruption are not nominated to the government. In no case will we support a government with the participation of entities threatening the foundations of liberal democracy or with a historical legacy of the liquidation of democracy in this country, i.e. in particular with the participation of the KSČM, SPD or a predominance of ANO." The post-election strategy further states: "We will demand reasonable guarantees to prevent abuse of power, for example, we will refuse to support candidates who would be in a constant conflict of interest."

The Pirates therefore really condition their support for the government on the democracy of their potential coalition partners. According to the cited post-election strategy, the Pirates reject cooperation with the SPD and the KSČM. Ivan Bartoš further states the refusal to support a government in which the ANO movement will have a majority, which is also in line with the cited part of the strategy. According to the cited post-election strategy, Bartoš also states a corrupt past and a conflict of interest as an obstacle to possible support for the government.

There is also a pirate post-election strategy for the 2019 European Parliament elections, which is in line with the previously cited document. It states:

" We want our program priorities and personnel requirements for the Commissioners to be reflected in the negotiations. European Commissioners must be competent people, without corruption scandals and ties to lobbyists of large corporations. (...) We therefore refuse to participate in the formation of a political group with undemocratic parties or parties that do not respect human rights or are fundamentally against the existence of the European Union as such."

SECTION B:

Jakub Michálek faced an unsuccessful attempt to dismiss him from the position of First Vice-Chairman of the Pirates at the turn of October and November 2019. In November 2019, he announced that he would not defend his position as Vice-Chairman and would continue to work in the Chamber of Deputies. He has been the chairman of the Pirates parliamentary group since October 2017. He commented on his dismissal on the Pirates forum in a post dated October 24, 2019, as follows:

"I said some time ago that I would not run again, that I want to fully concentrate on leading the club and leave the work in the republican presidency to someone else who has fresh enthusiasm to move things forward. We have a lot of new, talented representatives and I want to take a break, finish my dissertation and devote more time to my loved ones."

MP Michálek then actually on January 7, 2020 defended the post of chairman of the Pirates parliamentary group in the Chamber of Deputies.

We assess the statement as true, as Michálek's post on the pirate forum confirms the words of MP Bartoš that Michálek had proclaimed his intention not to defend the post of party vice-chairman even before the case of his dismissal. However, we were unable to find out from public sources whether this was actually the case in the summer of 2019.
